bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [Hugh S. Cumming], October 26, 1921

div1.p: Carter agrees to send Surgeon General Cumming a synopsis of a lecture on either malaria or yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to [Hugh S. Cumming], October 26, 1921
div1.opener:
Lecture for
Public Health Institute.
H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General,
(On Waiting Orders)
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 26, 1921.
Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
As requested by Bureau letter of October 24/21, I have the honor
to inform you that I will send you a statement within the next two
weeks as a synopsis of a lecture on either malaria or yellow fever
as the Bureau may desire. Of the two I should think that malaria
would be of greater practical interest to an audience in the U. S.
In my opinion to attempt to include both subjects in one lecture
would of necessity result in a treatment so sketchy as to be of
little if any value on either.

If, however, the Bureau wishes the two to be treated in one
lecture I will naturally attempt to do so--only, I am sure, with the
above result.
div1.closer: Respectfully, Assistant Surgeon General, (On Waiting Orders).
